Literally every Podcaster and information/opinion show does that. That still doesn't change the arguments or the facts at hand simply being capable of retrieving them in real-time to double check the accuracy of your own argument and the claims of the guest. replies.text: Well, the crime stats are off of reports, not cases prosecuted‚Ä¶ but NOT prosecuting criminals encourages repeat offenders to commit more crimes, not the opposite. If a criminal knows they‚Äôll get a slap on the wrist and be out of jail in a short period of time for Grand Theft Auto, they‚Äôre going to do it again because the consequences are worth the risk‚Ä¶ That said, it‚Äôs not the lack of prosecution that effects the crime stats, it‚Äôs the lack of police on the ground to respond and take reports. I‚Äôd argue that more crime is still happening, but people aren‚Äôt even bothering to call the police or make reports, especially because of the anti-police sentiment, they are less likely to call the cops and make a report in the first place. Those who are calling the cops are normal people, not woke-skulled Liberals, moderates and Republicans and Liberal Democrats that don‚Äôt enjoy being victims of crime‚Ä¶ So, it‚Äôs the lack of cops, cops not policing areas for fear of getting shot, police retiring at higher rates like Sean pointed out, and the fact that less crimes are reported overall‚Ä¶ but it doesn‚Äôt mean the crimes aren‚Äôt happening, and that‚Äôs the most disingenuous argument by Sam Seder. He‚Äôs an absolute fool if he think under funded and reduced staff in police forces doesn‚Äôt directly correlate to their inability to respond to most crimes, and when police don‚Äôt respond to a call about a crime that isn‚Äôt as high on the priority hierarchy, then the people just give up and stop reporting in general. Do you know how many times I was a victim of a crime in my life and I didn‚Äôt report it? Many many times. replies.text: Admittedly, Sean is far better at it than most people, but Internet Debates, in general, are relatively pointless, because discussions that take place in a Virtual Venue, where the Participants are physically separated by an Unknown Distance, has a sort of Dehumanizing/Dissociative Effect that enables the Participants to treat each other like garbage, because it doesn‚Äôt really FEEL ‚ÄúReal‚Äù, so it creates a Sense of Disconnect where it doesn‚Äôt really FEEL like it matters what you say, or how you say it, because you aren‚Äôt actually WITH the Other Participants, in the Same Vicinity as them, which removes the Incentive for Civility because the Threat of Potential ‚ÄúConsequences‚Äù is diminished by Default, which has a tendency to devolve into Snarky Catty Petty High School Mean Girl Behavior, which is further amplified by the Insane Tribalistic Zealotry that is rampant EVERYWHERE on the Internet, All of which adds up to the complete opposite of a productive or worthwhile conversation (along with about a Million OTHER Reasons that I have written about, at length, elsewhere).

replies.author: @vaeringjar1387
replies.text:
@salty4 Okay, it's clear which side you're on here.  Seder wasn't justifying anything; he was contradicting Sean, which isn't the same thing.  He did it by playing semantic games and misrepresenting what Sean said, in order to make his statistics work, and pivoting when they didn't.  For example:  Sean brings up New Orleans as a specific example for exploration, and Seder says "let's talk about national numbers," then Sean talks about the national numbers, and when that didn't work, Seder says "let's talk about Chesa Boudin and San Francisco."  Sean talks about that, and Seder moves onto Connecticut.  He's also condescending as hell, expressing disdain for what Sean knows and doesn't know, and saying things like "I imagine you'd hate rehabilitation programs."


Also, saying the rioters "were overdoing it" is extremely insulting when at least 19 people are dead because of their actions, and countless other lives have been ruined by the financial and social damage done to the neighborhoods that had to endure the riots.

replies.author: @renshawjoshua
replies.text:
I'm curious what you define "bad faith" means. Because what I consider bad faith is cherry picking a bunch of data and trying to wrap it around a narrative you are trying to construct that you know to be false. And then gishgalloping all around a subject just tossing those bits of data out there without any context; and when Sam brings up context it is just ignored and then hops to some other completely unrelated point and never answering straight-forward and direction questions. Questions that you know answering completely obliterates your argument.

If you want the best example of this: It's when Sam asks him, multiples times at different points, "So you are saying that police officer recruitment and/or retiretimes and/or people quitting is due to the George Floyd Effect even though you see similiar recruitment and/or retirements and/or people quitting in all industries during Covid. Would you attribute those other industries to the George Floyd Effect?"

Well the clear answer to that is: No. He can't address all of the other industries have the exact same systemic effect applying to it because then there is no "special" dynamic within policing, and then there is no George Floyd Effect. Because that it the logical followthrough the second you provided that context. 

So lets talk about "bad faith" again, shall we? Do you not consider it not just bad faith, but also just outright dishonesty, to deliberately leave out context that you, me, and everybody watching this video can immediately identify removes his point as soon as it is provided? If his goal is "the truth", right? Why would he not provide all of the details that develop that truth and choose to only hyper-focus that justify a world0view that he wants to have. And he wants you to have. And it just-so-happens that world-view just-so-happens to disproportionatelynegatively impact communities of color, communities of poverty, and communities that are economically disadvantaged.  For whatever reason aligns with the world-view that is shared to virulent racists.

Which, as you know, is coincidental. 

So the elements of argumentation that don't disproportionately impact those communities? Those are never included or addressed for some reason. And even when Sam points out these things in this discussion and makes him aware of these things? For some reason he doesn't change his perspective or his content. The next day, and the day after, and the weeks, months, etc after will continue to provide content that ignores that context and he continues to provide A very deliberate narrative that doesn't address any of the issues that Sam brought up here.

Still has not been addressed to this day.

@Eon-Blue I agree that you are correct. But that is the problem with content like this and Jordan Peterson and etc and why it is so insidious.

I‚Äôll give you a great example: 13/50

Black people are 13% of the population and represent 50% of the convicted violent crime in the US.

Now that is factual information. 

But you can‚Äôt just state that and just leave it hanging. When you begin to explain to people that crime heavily correlates with poverty (for obvious reasons that somebody with a good job, nice house, and good life is much less likely to just randomly go strong-arm a gas station than somebody that lives in a shit ghetto, has no opportunities for work, doesn‚Äôt know how they are going to keep the lights on). When you explain how generation wealth works; and how a historic lineage of 400 years of slavery, followed by 90 years of Jim Crow laws that prohibits black families from obtaining money or housing to pass down to their children and grandchildren. When you explain the housing acts, the redlining, the cycle of imprisonment, how schools are funded by property taxes so inner-city schools are underfunded unlike high property-value surrounded suburban schools, dozens more examples.

This context explains why 13/50 exists. And when the problem is understood; then you can begin to provide solutions that would actually address the underlying societal problems. You would solve 13/50.

But people like this don‚Äôt do that. 

They just say 13/50 and that‚Äôs it. And then will give you an anecdote that a black guy once beat up a white guy or something. That

replies.author: @adolfolerito6744
replies.text:
@h8uall66‚Äã‚Äã‚Å†  apparently I‚Äôm already doing better, because you missed all the nuance in the conversation, exactly because you‚Äôre used to people like Sam Seder dumbing everything down at what they think it‚Äôs the level of their audience (to whom they afford very little respect).

Sean explained how the ‚ÄúGeorge Floyd effect‚Äù was one of the *primary factors* for the post-June 2020 increase in violent crime, of which he attributes about 50% to 60% of causality due to consequences like advocacy for specific laws that made policing harder, rising anti-police sentiment, with all the related aspects, that drove many seasoned police officers to relocate or retire (and it did do so, because there‚Äôs an avalanche of statements from Police unions and records that directly attribute retirements to this factor), and several other factors.
This is very different from the ‚ÄúALL OF THE INCREASE in crime is because of the George Floyd riots‚Äù reasoning that Sam Seder tries to continuously pin on Sean even when Sean repeats to him that he never said those exact words‚Ä¶. and that logic that Sam Seder uses is the same one that you have adopted as well: dumbing down the conversation to single, generic points, ignoring very precise statements and cherry picking data while ignoring all correlations that don‚Äôt support your ideological view. Luckily you at least followed the video by yourself, without having an entire team goggling stuff for you and shouting it from the other side of the room.
Then Sean explains how the trajectory of the reforms that caused the increase in crime in 2020 had been already partially traced even before the riots, he makes the example of ‚Äúraise the age‚Äù that was passed in 2018, which he indicates as having made it harder to arrest youthful offenders. He makes several examples of the reforms that were motivated by the George Floyd riots, from the general defunding of law enforcement agencies around the nation after June 2020, to specific examples like the funding cuts to the LAPD, the Minneapolis PD, etc. or the disbandment of the Street Crime Unit in NYC (a very effective primarily plainclothes unit) which happened just a few weeks after Floyd‚Äôs death as an undeniable direct response to the anti-police sentiment.
He makes the example of New Orleans, and how it implemented the same fund-cutting, unit-dismantling reforms that were literally advocated by the George Floyd riots, which were enacted before the pandemic took place, yet lead to the same exact rises in crime that Sam Seder attributes uniquely to the pandemic.

Sean‚Äôs reasoning is extremely clear, but if you‚Äôre used to just slogans, don‚Äôt know the specific laws that were enacted and the data that took effect after them, and especially if you ask a question like ‚Äúwhich reforms?‚Äù, after ignoring the examples that were just made, and follow that question up with a completely unrelated topic, someone with the memory of a goldfish might forget the points that were made and will think that the previous question ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt answered‚Äù.

The main argument that Sean makes is that a number of significant, often politically motivated criminal justice reforms (like defunding law enforcement agencies), contributed to causing a rise in violent crime from the late 2010s onwards, and that the George Floyd riots acted as a catalyst for more of those reforms to come into place at the same time (to which again, he made examples), leading to a measurable spike in violent crime right from June 2020 (Floyd died on May 25) that progressed to the point that several of those measures had to be rolled back specifically to contrast the rise in crime that they incentivized.

Only by applying the worst degree of bad faith, selective listening, and lack of nuance would you be able to miss the amount of stuff that you (and Sam Seder) left out.

The fact that you are saying ‚ÄúBut Sam did blah blah‚Äù should tell you, Sean is not good at debating.  Sam is not good at debating, either, and he controlled this debate using simple techniques. replies.author: @CovocNexus
replies.text:
@chrlpolk I always find it funny when people argue "you aren't objective" because you agree with someone's position. Not only is it an unfalsifiable claim. The same logic could be applied to you. Unless you somehow believe you are above bias. 

There are tons of Religion debates, or Abortion debates where people on one side argue the person representing them didn't do a good job. Most people don't go into debates to have their minds changed, they are looking to see in the person argues their position well. And a lot of people are willing to accept when someone didn't argue their position well. 

You assume Sean doesn't know these debate tactics, but I'd argue that he's just one of those "I'd rather have a discourse than a debate" type of guys. I mean the man has been on countless debates, he just believes (naively I might add) that he shouldn't stoop to their level.

I am a random person on the internet yet you believe to know enough about me to state that "I live in an echo chamber." Crazy.

Sam was always going to "control" this debate as Sean was on HIS platform. He was asking the questions. He and his producers controlled the medium. It was Sean and his laptop vs Sam, his producers and their multiple laptops. This was not a moderated debate. This was more like an interview. 

All that being said, Sean did address Sam's major points and refuted them. Compare how hesitant Sam became to argue his usual positions once he knew Sean was knowledgeable. The same man that constantly argued that poverty drives crime, like gospel, started adding caveats, and arguing for multiple causes.

replies.author: @chrlpolk
replies.text: @CovocNexus I agree with Sean‚Äôs position.  But I also took a few debate courses.  Sam intentionally led Sean and controlled this debate.  Sam is better at it because he employed simple techniques.  That has nothing yo do with Sean‚Äôs facts.  The thing is, Sam didn‚Äôt have to prove Sean wrong, at all.  Sam only had to discredit Sean as an authoritative voice to be the messenger.  Which he did at the get-go, and Sean let him.  Sean called him out at the end for trying to ‚Äúgotcha‚Äù him; actually, Sam just derailed the debate topic, is all.  And Sam coyly responded, ‚ÄúI was just exploring.‚Äù üòÇü§£ü§£

author: @SmallTownResident
text:
Sam's tactics- Ask his opponents to repeat the same point over and over again in hopes that he catches him slipping so he can attempt a "gotcha" moment. When the moment never comes or fails flat out, resort back to strawmanning his opponent with "SO what you're saying is...." or "So you think that". 

Overall, I think Sean did okay because he was simply more factually based and rational but the problem is he was WAAAAYYYY too soft! He allowed Sam to talk all over him and let him steer the conversation wherever he wanted it to go. Sam pretty much got to ask the questions the entire time and Sean rarely if ever pressed him on his stupid claims. Sean should have gone more on the offense. You can't let a glorified sophist like Sam talk too much because it'll give the illusion that he is making good points. The only way to slay such a disingenuous weasel like Sam is to press him and make sure he doesn't get to dominate the conversation.

author: @Douglemagne
text:
Awwww.... Sean.... you missed a big opportunity. While Sam was reading that article FOREVER, I was googling the article (which you should have done, too) and then its sources and it turns out the reported data they were using was combined blocks of 8-12 year periods.... which absorbed the massive spike in crime during the BLM riots because it ALSO contained the subsequent decreases in crime that came after the furor died down... delivering the relatively humble +/-20% decrease over the decade long period. There is obviously something significant happening in CT, but that doesn't prove or disprove anything you guys were talking about. It might be fun to chase the CT rabbit hole and see where it goes one day (my guess is a large criminal gang composed of police was broken up in the 1990's just like in Los Angeles), but it's not representative of anything except that it DOES show that zooming in on the data supplied by Sam proves Sean's point, not Sam's.

I figure you will know everything there is to know about CT within moments of exiting the stream and you might have already bemoaned this moment on your own without my help. You're welcome anyway, Sean.

I applaud and thank you for going on that man's ridiculous show and shining a light on him even if you weren't as prepared as you could have been.
